There are conflicting stories about those programmes, but they certainly are not democratically accountable. They do not appear to be as effective as they might be. Indeed, the article went on to say:

"Whatever the merits of the missions as emergency programmes, they stress quantity over quality. Meanwhile, Venezuela's public infrastructure, such as roads and hospitals, is crumbling. A deficit of 1.5 million housing units is widening. Only a quarter of the 11,000 new houses needed each year are being built, because of the public sector's incompetence and its unwillingness to involve the private sector."

That may well be. I respect The Economist; it is one of the most respected journals for producing balanced articles. It may be that the person who wrote that had a biased view, but there is no doubt in my mind that the Venezuelan economy could perform better.
Another article in The Economist—it might be by the same author; I do not know—on 31 January 2006 stated:
"Fiscal profligacy will keep the public finances in deficit, despite high oil prices."
It continued:

"Most non-oil investment will continue to be put off by the uncertain legal and regulatory regimes and by price and exchange controls . . . The Ministry of Finance has been overborrowing in recent months, and has built up substantial Treasury cash balances".
As has been mentioned, President Chavez has taken on other south American countries' debts. For example, Venezuela has taken on £538 million of Argentine debt. The same pertains to Ecuador.

The President is trying to use the oil wealth to buy influence. That is not unprecedented elsewhere, provided it is done in a benign way. I hope that we can see that it is done in a benign way. We can see from this constructive debate that it is important that south America should be brought to the fore in this Parliament more often and more positively. We have always had good trading relationships with south America and they are, on the whole, friends of ours. We should maintain good trading and diplomatic links, and the debate has been a helpful and positive step. I hope that we can now reach more normal relations after the unfortunate remarks made in past months.

speech.speakeroffice: The Minister for the Middle East
speech.p: May I say what a pleasure it is to take part in this debate under your chairmanship, Mr. Cook? You have long experience in diplomacy and foreign affairs and I am sure that you have enjoyed this debate as much as I have. It has been a good debate.

I congratulate my hon. Friend the Member for Elmet (Colin Burgon) on securing the debate, which I am answering on behalf of our noble Friend Lord Triesman, who has responsibility for Latin America in the Foreign Office. I welcome the opportunity to discuss Venezuela and the points raised in today's debate. Venezuela is an important country, and I shall try to explain why we believe that. We have heard some of the reasons already. Venezuela is important regionally and globally, which is reflected in the importance we attach to our bilateral relationship with it. That is why the debate is important. It gives us the opportunity to put that on the record. I will come to the points raised by my hon. Friend in a moment, but we have heard a great number of interesting points.

The hon. Member for Shrewsbury and Atcham (Daniel Kawczynski) stressed the importance of the fight against drugs, which I shall deal with in the body of my reply. He is quite right. My hon. Friend the Member for Hemsworth (Jon Trickett) spoke, and I am glad he did, about the eyeball-swivelling right-wingers on the fringes of American politics who assume that they have a divine right to decide how people should vote and that it is possible to react in any way they want to the decision of the democratic expression of the people in south America and Latin America.

The hon. Member for The Wrekin (Mark Pritchard) warned us about the scale of the task facing the Venezuelan Government in tackling the dreadful poverty that is evident in the country. It was a good warning. My hon. Friend the Member for Hayes and Harlington (John McDonnell), who has gone now, paid tribute to the women of Venezuela—quite properly, in my view—and listed some of the achievements of the Government in tackling poverty and its social consequences, especially as they affect women. It was important to put that on the record.

My hon. Friend the Member for North-West Leicestershire (David Taylor) reminded us how important co-operation with Venezuela is, especially in the field of drugs. It is a huge problem. I will try to expand on the subject in a moment. His question about a wider debate about American foreign policy is for another occasion and another venue. I seem to spend half my life dealing with that question, but that is for another place.

My hon. Friend the Member for Islington, North (Jeremy Corbyn) gave us an enlightening speech on the historical context, and sketched out some of the reasons why, despite the fact that oil has been around in Venezuela for a long time, it remains a poor country when it ought to be one of the richest in the world, not just in south America. That has ramifications elsewhere as well. My hon. Friend hinted at many reasons why that should be so. He mentioned one that, I think, is the most important. The capacity to govern ought to flow naturally from a democratic election and the decision of the people. If we try to undermine that for partisan reasons, whether they are political, economic or anything else, that is dangerous. That is one of the reasons why Venezuela has for so long had a reputation for instability, when it had democratic elections back in 1947. Since 1958, it has been a reasonably stable democracy by south American standards, although there have been some intervals when that has not been the case. I am glad that my hon. Friend raised that point.

My hon. Friend the Member for Manchester, Central (Tony Lloyd) has great experience in these matters. He boiled the importance of the changes that President Chavez and his Government are attempting to implement down to the specific example of a young woman who he met in Venezuela. It is important that we remind ourselves that we are talking not about abstract, high-political notions, but about people and the changes that ought to be happening in such countries. I was glad to hear my hon. Friend do that.

The hon. Member for Hereford (Mr. Keetch) has visited Venezuela and seen it for himself. I cannot see any sign that our business relations with Venezuela have cooled as a consequence of statements that have been made over the past few weeks. I am glad to say that. As I will try to argue, it is an important country for us and for the world.

The hon. Gentleman highlighted some important worries about human rights in Venezuela. It is not pro-American to say that one is worried about human rights in any country. It shows a concern about human rights and about how we promote and protect them. No matter which country we look at, that concern ought to be at the heart of foreign policy in any democracy. That is the case in this country, and I am glad that the hon. Gentleman raised the subject. It is very encouraging that there is a free press in Venezuela as well as vibrant news media that are not afraid to reflect the concerns of people from all parts of society. We must rejoice in that and do our best to protect it.

I was very glad that the hon. Member for Cotswold (Mr. Clifton-Brown) made the speech that he did. I have always been a believer in Gramsci's dictum—I never get it right but I think it is about optimism of the spirit and pessimism of the intellect. It is right that we should cast a sceptical eye across any country when we attempt to analyse where it is likely to move. Of course there are problems in Venezuela, as in many other places. The hon. Gentleman expressed a different view from that of some of my hon. Friends about how those issues, including poverty, might best be addressed, but I respect the fact that he has cast a sceptical eye over the question. I know that he feels passionately that Venezuela and its democratic system should be helped whenever that is possible.

The relationship between the United Kingdom and Venezuela is an active one. We work effectively together in several fields, including crime, counter-narcotics and energy. We have an important commercial relationship, as hon. Members have explained. Indeed, UK companies hold large investments in Venezuela. It is the third biggest market for the United Kingdom in Latin America, and it accounts for almost 10 per cent. of our exports in that area of the world—a figure surpassed, I believe, only by Brazil and Mexico.

We work with the Venezuelan authorities in tackling crime and corruption, which are a major impediment to social and economic development throughout Latin America. Recently we sponsored a conference in Venezuela on the role of the police in Latin America and 14 countries from across the region were represented. The event provided a useful space for debate and for the sharing of experiences from the region on transformation and the restructuring of the police.

Our embassy in Caracas is currently running a project aimed at helping Venezuela to develop its national capacity in the energy sector. My hon. Friend the Member for North-West Leicestershire reminded us that there is a world beyond the most immediate of concerns. One thing that worries me as a former Education Minister is that we do not do enough to export the marvellous skills and abilities of this country's further education sector and universities. They do sterling work that is of relevance in this context. I think that the hon. Member for Cotswold raised the point, and the hon. Member for Hereford certainly did, that the economy could be doing better.

Probably, upskilling—to use that awful term—is the most immediate way to achieve an improvement in that regard. We want the Venezuelan economy to improve. It will help if we can work closely with Venezuela on that: it will promote the transfer of knowledge and skills in several key areas. We have close links with the state oil company in Venezuela and with Venezuelan universities and the appropriate Ministries, as well as other public and private organisations that are involved in providing, supporting and developing education and training to the energy sector in Venezuela. Shell, BP and the Wood group are also making efforts to share their expertise to the benefit of Venezuela, as a reflection of their policies of social responsibility, so that they can work as partners in the development of the country's main natural resources.

Those resources are very extensive. We have heard about only one of them today: oil. However, in fact there are extensive and large deposits of other minerals, such as coal, iron ore, bauxite and gold. The country has remarkable natural resources. It is to be hoped that those resources will help to transform the life of the young woman about whom my hon. Friend the Member for Manchester, Central spoke. If the economy could be tailored to make real use of those minerals, that should and could happen.

I do not know whether we need reminding, but in a world of rapidly depleting resources, Venezuela is a great natural resource for the whole world. As my hon. Friend the Member for Islington, North hinted, it is also a very fertile country. It should have much stronger agriculture, to feed itself and its neighbours, and to enable it to export around the world. My hon. Friend is right to point out that issue. I have talked about the potential for mining precious minerals—coal is a precious mineral these days—but we need to be careful; many agricultural economies have been destroyed by a sudden rush for mineral wealth. We should be able to help the Venezuelans with that issue, and we ought to do it.

As for the vexed question of drugs, under our EU presidency and in co-operation with the Venezuelan authorities—it was good co-operation—we ran the first meeting of drugs observatories of Latin America and the Caribbean and the EU in Caracas. The meeting reaffirmed the principle of shared responsibility, as well as the role that drugs observatories can play in informing the formulation of policies to carry out effective drug strategies.

I shall not have time to expand on that matter as I wanted to, but as we have had greater success against the go-fast boats in the Caribbean that take cocaine to America and the Caribbean islands the drug traffickers have switched their attention. Venezuela is suffering as a consequence of the transhipping of drugs across Venezuela towards Guyana and down to Brazil. The drugs go to the ports in those countries, where they are shipped to west Africa. They then come up through west Africa and into Europe. The people involved are endlessly resourceful. They are well financed. They are having a tremendously corrosive effect in the northern part of south America, and we must work closely with the Venezuelans on that.

Will the Minister confirm, for the record, that there has been tremendous co-operation from both Cuba and Venezuela in attempts to end the drugs trade in the region and protect the lives of many poor people in Europe and north America?

I know that we have co-operated closely with the Venezuelans, and I have a little knowledge about co-operation with Cuba, but I am sure that my hon. Friend, who knows a lot about the subject, is right on that score. It is important. Addiction to crack cocaine and the poison that young people in Europe stick into their veins and up their noses does not just affect communities in Europe, such as his constituency and mine and those of other hon. Members present. It has a corrosive effect also in Venezuela and Colombia.

I am sure that my hon. Friend will agree that co-operation is vital in this matter, because we shall not resolve the damage that is done in this country without good partners in Latin America. It is also in Venezuela's interest, as it becomes the victim of drug trafficking of the kind that my hon. Friend has described. So does north America, in the end. We all need partnership on those issues, not confrontation.

I could not have expressed it better. The problem is a serious one for all of us, and my hon. Friend is right. I am confident that we can work in partnership with Venezuela and other countries in the region. If we do not, we shall all suffer as a consequence.

Is the Minister aware that drug enforcement officers from this country, who currently help in Latin American countries, are being withdrawn because of changes to budgets? If he is not aware of that, will he undertake to investigate the matter and ensure that we put more, not fewer, drugs officers in those countries?
I will undertake to give the hon. Gentleman a reply on that. I know that our drugs liaison officers around the world do a superb job, and I shall try to find out about that for him.

In conclusion, I hope that hon. Members will agree that it is in the interests of the United Kingdom to remain engaged with the region. That is why the debate in which my hon. Friend has brought the issue to our attention is so important. What happens in Latin America, including Venezuela, matters a great deal to us all. We shall not always see eye to eye with some its Governments; nor will we shy away from criticism when we judge it to be necessary, but our policy remains to seek constructive engagement with Venezuela. We have much to gain from working together.

Order. Before we commence the next debate, let me ensure that everyone understands that there is a two-minute discrepancy between the analogue timepiece on the wall and the electronic ones by which we determine our timing.

I stray with some trepidation into a discussion of how judicial error is managed and compensated. Although my parents suggested that I pursue the legal profession, I did not do so. I chose otherwise and have only a lay knowledge of the law.

My point of interest in compensation for judicial error stemmed initially from the experience of a constituent, Mr. Paul Robinson, who lives in Netherseal, in the south of my constituency. He was convicted on an indecent assault charge by a 10 to two majority verdict in May 2003. He was sentenced to a two-year community rehabilitation order, ordered to pay prosecution costs and placed on the sex offenders register. His appeal was heard in October 2004. The appeal was allowed and the conviction was quashed. I shall not recount the details of the case. The purpose of this debate is to illustrate the implications of judicial error for my constituent and to ask questions about the implications for the judicial process and the judge in question.

The point at issue that led to the error was that the defence intended to call a witness who had been named by the appellant as having seen her shortly before the claimed offence took place. The defence took the view that if doubt could be cast on her account, a fundamental aspect of her case would fail. The judge, of his own volition and without prompting from the prosecution, indicated that the question went to credit and that the defence was bound by the witness's answer. The defence pursued the point by returning to the witness who could have been called and pointing out the possible evidence that he might give. The prosecution were not called to comment at all during the exchange, at the end of which, as the appeal court put it:
"The judge dealt very peremptorily with the matter. The Crown were not called on for any assistance. He simply said: 'It goes to credit, I am not allowing it, thank you.'"
The appeal court then gave its assessment of the decision:

"It had, in our judgment, become clear, when the judge made this ruling, that it was a key issue in the case whether the complainant had been in Netherseal or Main Street at around 8.30 on the morning of Tuesday 7th May. She said that she went there specifically to talk, among others, to"
the possible witness,
"and that he was there. His evidence, had he been allowed to give it, would, as we understand it, have been that he never saw"
the complainant
"at the bus stop at any time during that week."

The appeal court went on to consider legal precedence in the matter. I shall not detain the Chamber by going into that, except to say that, from my reading as a lay person, the outcome seems pretty clear. In giving its judgment, the appeal court put the matter bluntly:
"In our judgment, the evidence of"
the potential witness

"in this case did plainly go to an issue in the case, namely, whether the complainant was or was not at the place where the offence is alleged to have occurred at the time that she alleged that it did occur.

We think the judge was wrong. We think that he was too hasty in reaching the conclusion that he did. He would have been better advised to have sought the assistance of the Crown. In the experience of this Court in doubtful situations such evidence is ordinarily admitted. Be that as it may, the evidence was not admitted in this case and it is our conclusion that, had the evidence been admitted, it is impossible to say that the decision of the jury would inevitably have been the same."
The appeal court then quashed the sentence.

It seems clear that my constituent's conviction was substantially based on the judicial error made. The appeal court did not hear the evidence in question although its content is referred to in the judgment. I wish to pursue two points, the first of which is the consequences for my constituent. His conviction received local publicity, as one would expect. Since then—and even after his successful appeal—he has been subject to harassment both locally and in his business activities. It is fair to say that his life has followed a dramatically altered and inferior course since his conviction. Although he has not spent a period in custody, he has been placed on the sex offenders register and met the required restrictions on his freedoms, which were relieved following the appeal.

My constituent is entitled to no compensation, which relates in part to the presumption that only a prison sentence should prompt compensation and also to the attitude taken to convictions that are shown to be unsafe. There is a reference in one of the cases that I examined to a distinction in some legal minds, according to which
"compensation goes only to those ultimately proved innocent, not to all those whose convictions are adjudged unsafe".

That was the conclusion reached in a divisional court in 2002. One can only be grateful that the apparent suggestion that an appellant must prove innocence was overturned at a subsequent appeal, the leading judgment stating that
"our criminal system, like that of most other states, does not provide for proof of innocence".

In my constituent's case, the appeal court chose not to hear the evidence that would have cast substantial doubt on the claims of the appellant, relying instead on the argument that the judge had erred. From my brief and inexpert review of other cases in which compensation has been considered, that approach is commonly taken. That appears to leave appellants at a disadvantage in terms of any compensation claim, in that it can seem that their case has succeeded only on technical grounds and not on the basis of evidence demonstrating that facts in the case were otherwise than those heard in court.

We set a very high bar for paying compensation, which is understandable in some respects. As a constituency MP, I sometimes receive angry correspondence about compensation paid when a person is released from prison after a wrongful conviction. That correspondence would be angrier still if compensation were payable when a conviction was overturned on a technicality alone. However, I feel it to be reasonable that, where evidence is available to suggest the probability that the appellant did not commit the offence—as was the case in this instance—it should be heard in addition to any argument over process or judicial error. That did not happen with my constituent.

My other point is about the consequence for the judge. It seems strongly arguable that his decision not to permit a witness to be heard and cross-examined, and for the jury to have made its own judgments on that process, had a material impact on the outcome of the case. It is worth recalling that the jury gave a majority verdict of 10 to two, and that even marginal alterations in the trial process might have made a substantial difference. We are talking about a witness would have questioned the presence of the complainant at the scene.

The straight answer is that I do not know what happened to the judge after his decision was corrected. Although I can appreciate that the objectivity and independence of the judiciary might be harmed by, say, the ability of a complainant to sue the judge for damages where their error causes harm, I would expect some accountability to be exercised for judicial error. On my observation, we instead enter into a polite and largely private world. Some of the texts that I have read, which were written by learned lawyers, point out that it can be argued that the appellate process offers some accountability, in that it demonstrates where a correction is required of a judge. Reversals are normally administered politely and with deference. As one learned commentator has said:
"personal attacks are politely concealed".
In my constituent's case the appeal comment is blunt in those terms.

It might be assumed that adverse appeal judgments were monitored and pursued with the judges involved. Are they, and, if so, how? It is also fair to say that the costs and risks of appeal must mean that only a proportion of cases of judicial error are appraised in that way. Only some cases of judicial error lead to a potential appeal, yet arguably all errors should be monitored and that monitoring should then be reflected in an appraisal of judicial performance.

It has been argued, again by a far more learned person than I, that the price of tolerating incompetent judges should be borne by society in order to protect the competent judges against the abuse of power by the Executive. The argument is essentially that we must put up with failure and error because to have the Executive sacking judges or reprimanding them publicly for their performance would affect their independence of judgment in weighing up particular cases and advising juries. If one accepts the argument that we must accept incompetence, one could reasonably add that the cost to the individual of an incompetent judge should also be borne by society as part of the cost of protecting the judiciary's independence.

There are, it seems, informal processes through which the Bar may pass on informed opinions of judicial performance. However they rely, as much in the legal profession does, on personal networks and exchanges which seem an inadequate means of assessing the performance of those whose actions have a profound bearing on the lives and well-being of individuals.

Public scrutiny is partially offered through the informed and less well-informed comments of the media. Judges are assessed on their performance in that way and are often criticised. That is also presumably monitored to some extent. Among the approaches that are adopted in some cases is the public scrutiny of administrative reports that show the productivity of courts. That is of some informative use, but it does not answer the need for accountability on the quality of judicial performance. It measures only the throughput of courts in getting cases listed and their leading to judgment. It does not address whether the performances have been adequate or not.

It would seem reasonable to have a periodic report that summarised the number of occasions a conviction was overturned in instances where judicial error was found by the higher court to be a contributory factor. Such a report could also set out examples of performance management, such as where judges have been asked to reflect on an adverse superior judgement. I see no reason why an individual should not be named in such a process. In other professions—we are all aware of what happens in the medical profession—acceptance of error and public scrutiny of fault are regarded as perfectly acceptable. Public recognition of error need not impinge on the independence of a judge's future deliberations.

While I have no great hopes that my constituent's experience will lead to any compensation or even to an apology from the judge responsible, I hope to hear from my right hon. and learned Friend the Minister what steps the Government are taking both to monitor and, where necessary, to establish management arrangements for the performance of judges. Failing that, if one accepts that judicial independence is compromised by any attempts to impose competence standards, I hope that we will have a framework for compensating those who suffer a lower barrier to entry than now.

speech.speakeroffice: The Minister of State, Department for Constitutional Affairs
speech.p: I congratulate my hon. Friend the Member for South Derbyshire (Mr. Todd) on making this case the subject of this debate. It is an individual case, but it raises a number of important and difficult points of principle. I shall deal with our overall approach and then address the mechanisms of accountability and complaint that we have established.

The judiciary in this country are of immense importance. It is down to them to ensure that justice is done, which includes taking away people's property or liberty where that is necessary in the interests of justice. By the same token, they take away people's reputations as part of the process. As a result of the enormously important position that the judiciary hold and their great powers, any errors that they make have far-reaching consequences.

My hon. Friend has given the example of the consequences that resulted from an error for one of his constituents. He also asked whether we should have to choose between the independence of the judiciary and high standards and whether we have to put up with errors and low standards in the judiciary because we just cannot go anywhere near the matter and nothing can be done because taking action would interfere with their independence.

We reject that sense that a choice has to be made. We should ensure that there is both absolute independence of the judiciary—they should be confident of their independence—and high standards. We must have both. We need the judges to be independent, and seen to be such, but we also need a system of redress and accountability for error or misconduct. Just as the judiciary should sustain public confidence, so should the rules about redress and accountability where error or misconduct has taken place.

My hon. Friend is right to say that there is a sense that the systems of complaint get fed into a dark, mysterious, secretive place and nobody knows what view is taken of the complaints or what is done about them. However good a system of complaint is, if it is mysterious and people do not know the outcomes, it will not ensure that public confidence is maintained.

Hitherto, judicial office holders who are criticised by the Court of Appeal have that drawn to their attention, usually through their presiding judge, who will consider whether any further action is necessary by way of giving advice, guidance or refresher training, or by changing their work load. That is not an open process. People will see the criticism in open court but nobody necessarily knows whether it has been drawn to the judge's attention, although it almost certainly will have been. People will not know the presiding judge's view or what action that judge has taken. There is a problem: although action can be taken, it is not seen by those who need to have confidence in the accountability of the judicial system.

My hon. Friend mentioned compensation. Although he is right that his constituent does not qualify for it, perhaps I may explain what the compensation schemes are and how they operate. The Home Office operates two compensation schemes. The first is a statutory scheme under section 133 of the Criminal Justice Act 1988, which places a duty on the Home Secretary to pay compensation where there are new or newly discovered facts in cases that are out of time for appeal which show beyond reasonable doubt that a miscarriage of justice occurred.

The second scheme is the Home Secretary's discretionary scheme. It applies only when someone has spent time in custody. To that effect, a person might have lost their livelihood and reputation and might feel great outrage, but the discretionary scheme none the less applies only to those who have lost their liberty. It is an ex gratia scheme and there are two bases for it: where there has been serious default by a public authority, which does not include the judiciary because they do not count as a public authority, and where there are exceptional circumstances, such as an accused person being completely exonerated at trial or on appeal. My hon. Friend's constituent would not qualify because, despite the appeal, he did not spend time in custody. Cases of judicial error can only be considered under the Home Secretary's discretionary scheme if someone has spent time in custody.

In the first scheme to which my right hon. and learned Friend referred, one of the tests is that new facts that demonstrate beyond reasonable doubt that the individual did not commit the offence in question are, effectively, disclosed. In my constituent's case, the Appeal Court could have heard the evidence of the individual who was not called in the original trial, but did not take that opportunity. I understand that it is common practice for the issue of process, if it is available, to dominate as a ground for the dismissal of an appeal, and that often the new evidence that was not heard before is not heard in the Appeal Court.

I take my hon. Friend's point entirely that if one is exonerated in a quicker and more expedited way, one none the less does not qualify for the section 133 statutory payment. I shall consider that further, particularly as to whether there is a gap such as he has described.

I have explained the discretionary scheme. There is also a provision that the Lord Chancellor has been prepared to consider requests for ex gratia payments in cases in which a judicial office holder has demonstrated some sort of personal misconduct. I want to mention also the new scheme for judicial complaints. In the past, Lord Chancellors have taken seriously cases in which Members of Parliament or members of the public have complained to them about judges, but one problem with that is that it has not been visible. Just as when the Court of Appeal makes a complaint about a judge it might be taken up by the presiding judge, the Lord Chancellor might have taken up such an issue with a judge, but nobody would know about it. That is one issue that the Constitutional Reform Act 2005 was introduced to address, so that while assuring the independence of the judiciary, we bring such complaints out of the polite and private world of the Inns of Court and gentlemen's clubs into proper transparency and accountability.

The reforms in the Act come into effect in April. A major plank of the reforms is the introduction of a statutory regime governing the investigation of allegations of judges' personal misconduct. The Lord Chancellor and the Lord Chief Justice will have joint responsibility for the scheme and for a new office of judicial complaints, which will be operational from 3 April. The office will support them in that new role and regarding the introduction of proper rules and regulations. Any regulations will be laid before Parliament so that, as with any other important system, one can see what the rules are and which bodies will apply them.

My right hon. and learned Friend refers to misconduct; there is a distinction between misconduct and error. In the case that I discussed, no one suggested that the judge did something indecent or improper, but simply that he made a mistake. How would that be handled in the process?
Judicial error is dealt with through appeals and the compensation scheme that I outlined. I will consider further what my hon. Friend said on that.

As my hon. Friend rightly points out, I am dealing with misconduct here, and the sorts of related issues about which people might complain, which are not necessarily described as errors, but are generally about people wanting to complain about the judiciary. I am talking about cases concerning matters that cannot be subject to appeal, but about which people feel aggrieved and want to make complaints. Hitherto, there was no proper process for such situations, but there will now be such a process under the Constitutional Reform Act. I was just taking the opportunity that my hon. Friend has created with this debate to remind hon. Members how the system will work, because it is all part of trying to ensure that we do not have to choose between independence and high standards or accountability; we want to have them all.

In addition to the new office of judicial complaints, there will be a judicial appointments and conduct ombudsman to oversee its operation. There will be a lay element to the consideration of any individual complaint. I remind hon. Members that Sir John Brigstocke was recently appointed to the ombudsman position; I am looking forward to meeting him tomorrow.

The reforms will ensure that we all understand that the judiciary are independent but that they live in a world in which people expect accountability and redress, and that people are less likely simply to assume that the right thing was done. "Leave it with me" is no longer good enough. If people think that something has gone wrong, they want it put right. That is part of the welcome change of people expecting public authorities to do the right thing and be accountable if they do not.

The winds of change that the new office of judicial complaints will bring into the judiciary will have a beneficial effect beyond even the question of personal misconduct. We do not want judges always to have to look over their shoulders, but we all know that if we might be answerable for something, we think about it with extra care. We want judges to be fearlessly independent but to have a sense of accountability, not just through the appeal process, but through a process that involves lay people and not just the courts.

I might not have been able to deal with my hon. Friend's constituent's sense of grievance, but I undertake to ensure that the Lord Chancellor sees the report of these proceedings and understands my hon. Friend's concerns. I shall also bring the issue to the attention of Sir John Brigstocke when I meet him tomorrow. There is a line of thought that colleagues should not even mention individual cases as it is all down to the judge and nobody should mention such cases in the House of Commons, but I do not agree. This is absolutely an appropriate subject for debate, and we might have to make an alteration if we find that my hon. Friend has identified a lacuna.
I am delighted to initiate the debate, not least because, as the Member of Parliament for Bridgwater for the past five years, I have lived with the threat of the closure of the ammunition plant.

Defence is a genuine interest of mine. I used to be an adviser to the Land Command, and I retain the rank of major in the Fusiliers and remain on the reserve list. Most importantly, I represent a constituency with a proud history of providing weapons and arms to the Army, Navy and Air Force—providing them with real means to do the job.

In Bridgwater, to put it crudely, we make bombs. We have done so efficiently, economically and successfully for more than 50 years—in fact, for just on 60 years. Most of my constituents who are involved at the plant are the best legal bomb makers in the business. They are true specialists and, needless to say, dedicated to their work. But next year, there may be no more work for them to do. Next year, the people who own the Royal Ordnance factory, as it used to be called, outside Puriton, intend to close the place. They reckon that they can buy what Britain needs elsewhere in the world, and cheaper. I think that they are misguided, and I am not alone by any means: 135 skilled people agree with me, and so does my parliamentary predecessor, Lord King of Bridgwater, who was Defence Secretary at the time of the first Gulf war and has an exemplary record with this country's armed forces, having also served as a young serviceman.

To shut the plant would be much more than a local blow; it would be a national disgrace. If taken to its logical conclusion, it could put the defence of the realm at risk. Even local people in an industrial town such as Bridgwater feel a sense of betrayal. We started making armaments in Bridgwater during the last war. It was a question of genuine necessity. Germany was stretching our military capabilities to the limits, so building the factory had to start as quickly as possible. At that time, of course, money was no object. They even dug a complete canal system from the Bristol channel to provide the water for the factory.

Over the years, that discrete little plant of 400 acres has churned out the propellant, bombs, missiles and everything else that we have needed for every theatre of conflict in which the United Kingdom has taken part since the second world war. It was the local Royal Ordnance factory that made the famous bouncing bomb. Its inventor, Sir Barnes Wallis, would probably be rotating in his grave if he realised what was going to happen to the factory that played such an important part in our history.

The bombs that came down on Saddam Hussein's bunkers were primed at Puriton. The final charges for many of our weapons of mass destruction are made and located in Bridgwater. The work force remain and will always remain special. Originally, they were recruited from throughout Britain, and they are people who do a very dangerous and vital job of keeping our defences on the straight and narrow.

The factory also maintains an exemplary safety record. Rarely has there been a problem, and no problem has ever involved an explosion. When the factory became a part of BAE Systems, and that did not happen under the present Government, there was a change—there was a can-do attitude. Even when the plant was under threat of closure two years ago, the entire work force volunteered for extra productivity to keep the plant going for BAE Systems. They went on to three shifts a couple of years ago, for obvious reasons. I know that because I have been working alongside the trade unions since I have been in Parliament, and the local management is also determined to try to keep the factory open.

I am afraid that crude economies are beating common sense into second place. BAE Systems is rationalising, rightly, for hard commercial reasons, but no Government should treat the defence of the country as a commercial venture, and no Government should ever be held hostage by any company, especially one such as BAE Systems. Let us consider the matter crudely: who will pack the bombs, load the bullets and enable the military to do the job that we all depend on it to do? Those are sensible questions to which as yet we have had no forthright answers. I have been in correspondence with Ministers, and Lord King of Bridgwater and I have had face to face meetings with Lord Drayson on this subject. However, I am told time and again that the decision has been made and the security of supply is safe. The official line is that there is nothing to worry about. BAE Systems is confident. In the manner of Mandy Rice-Davies, they would say that, wouldn't they? BAE Systems probably cannot be bothered with a little bomb factory that ticks over nicely but will never make a real bomb in the financial sense.

I should declare an interest. As a serving bomb disposal officer in the Territorial Army, I am especially keen on bombs. My hon. Friend is making a powerful case about appropriate sovereignty in our defence procurement systems. Indeed, this area is covered by the defence industrial strategy, which I realise is not in the direct realm of the Minister. Does my hon. Friend share my concern that it is not just the factory in his constituency but also the small and medium-sized enterprises that serve it that could be affected?
I thank my hon. Friend for that thoughtful intervention. I agree totally, and I defer to him in the area of bomb disposal. It is not one in which I personally would ever get involved.

I realise that it is not this Minister but Lord Drayson who deals directly with this subject. In the meeting that I had with the noble Lord, I was not utterly convinced that he had grasped the complexities of the situation in respect of the defence of the realm. He understood the financial side, but, on the practical side, I was not entirely sure that he understood the long-term ramifications.

I totally agree with my hon. Friend. Many of the companies that supply directly to the plants are British companies. After they go, I wonder where defence supplies will be obtained. There have been many questions in the House on this issue.

The land on which the factory stands is close to the M5. I suspect that it would fetch a large packet for housing. I wonder if that has crept into the BAE accountants' heads. I rather hope not, but I have a horrible feeling that I may be wrong.

National security should never depend on commercial interests. I am told, for example, that the United States navy is seriously worried about future supplies, as the Puriton factory provides a type of explosive that is hard to obtain from any other source. Rumour has it that the Pentagon is trying to persuade my local plant to make more of the stuff so that the American military can stockpile it. The Americans are well aware of the skills of the British work force and certainly have no intention of shopping around the world, unlike us.

Naturally, one can buy things that go bang from all corners of the globe, but the secret is to buy quality. One certainly does not want things going bang unexpectedly—that would be completely unacceptable and, of course, dangerous to those in my hon. Friend's line—or failing to go bang when they should.

A few years ago, the British military tried to save cash by buying bullets from the far east, specifically India. But riflemen with rifles that refuse to fire are no good to any army. The foreign goods were quietly and, unfortunately, expensively scrapped. The factory in Bridgwater made up the difference in supplies, at some cost to itself.

I have an abiding distrust of the defence procurement process. For example, how did the highly trained experts responsible for RAF Yeovilton, which is in Somerset, manage to order an expensive new control tower which, when built, did not give views of the aircraft?

Those of us with contacts in the military well remember Operation Sharp Sword. It was a huge training exercise in the Gulf before the action started. Unfortunately, things went wrong. The boots melted—I have some experience of that myself, it is not a new thing—and tanks and helicopters were instantly clogged up with sand. How many times have vehicles been taken to desert situations and refitted in theatre, instead of before they leave this country? The lads on the ground renamed the exercise Operation Broken Penknife, which is hardly inspiring when one is talking about the defence of the realm and putting the lives of our troops at risk.

Rumour also has it that France could be the new source of some of these supplies. The French make splendid cheese and wine, but I would not bank on their ability to keep us in weapons or explosives. The French record on safety and security trails a long way behind ours. I am told that a consignment of explosives was recently shipped from France to Somerset so that the experts at Puriton could have a good look at it—could evaluate it on our behalf. The product was passable, but the security at the French depot where it was collected was non-existent: the lorry driver drove in and picked it up and no one was there. No wonder the Americans are twitchy. But we should be twitchy, too. This is no time for complacency.

Somerset has the only ordnance plant that makes propellant. It is now facing closure because of the peace dividend. Everybody hoped that we would not grumble, but this sad saga is really about price, not peace. I believe that making weapons is far too important to leave to the marketplace; that has been proved to be the case on many occasions. Closing our arms factory would obviously be a bitter blow to Bridgwater, but it would also be a dangerous step for our national security. I appeal to the Minister to intervene—to use his muscle—before it is too late.

Even when the Prime Minister was questioned on this topic during Question Time, he said that he was happy that the security of supply and the assurances given by BAE Systems were sufficient. They are only sufficient until something goes wrong. When it goes wrong, the blame will sit squarely on the shoulders of the Government of the day—that may not be this Government or its Ministers—for allowing this to happen in the first place.

speech.speakeroffice: The Minister of State, Ministry of Defence
speech.p: I congratulate the hon. Member for Bridgwater (Mr. Liddell-Grainger) on securing this debate and on providing me with the opportunity to speak on these important issues. I acknowledge the hon. Gentleman's expertise and his involvement—the role he has played in Her Majesty's armed forces. I also pay tribute to the hon. Member for North-East Milton Keynes (Mr. Lancaster) on the role he has played.

As the hon. Member for Bridgwater will be aware, we discussed procurement generally in depth in a defence debate on 2 February. We largely dealt with the recently published defence industrial strategy—the DIS—and the progress we were making on our major programmes. That, of course, affects the way procurement in this country is managed and run in the future. The hon. Gentleman raised a number of issues and some of them fall within the ambit of the DIS, so I think it is worth setting that out again. He has made some trenchant criticisms of past procurement, and many of the points he made have been taken on board by the present Government. We have learned lessons and we are trying to put in place a new construct to assist us. If I briefly touch on the DIS, I hope that it will give the hon. Gentleman comfort in respect of some of the areas of tangential concern that he raised.

We published the DIS on 15 December. It has been well received across industry and by the trade unions. There has been a general welcome for it in this House and the other place, recognising the new partnership between industry and the Government on which it is based. The DIS gives industry, for the first time, real clarity on what we require, how we will go about obtaining that and how we can maintain onshore those elements of industry that are fundamental to our national security. In some sectors, the market is healthily competitive; in others, such as maritime and guided weapons, change is unquestionably required. Industry must make its commercial decisions in responding to the DIS, but we expect companies to show leadership by aligning their businesses to the realities of the future.

Maintaining the ability to support and upgrade the significant programme of new platforms and new equipment that we are bringing into service will be crucial. We clearly cannot afford a cradle-to-grave industry in all sectors. However, the higher-value areas—those that provide the most secure and interesting careers—are often the very ones in which we need to keep our freedom of military action.

We have taken the bold step of setting out the realities, which many would say is long overdue, and we have done so early enough for companies to be able to plan for the transition to a sustainable future while they are well employed. It was John F. Kennedy who said, "The time to fix the roof is when the sun is shining." I am pleased to report that industry and the Ministry of Defence are wasting no time in implementing the DIS.

I think the hon. Member for Bridgwater was seeking to claim the moral high ground and to call into question perhaps not the integrity but the capacity of BAE Systems. May I remind him of some of the history? The royal ordnance factories were vested as Royal Ordnance plc on 2 January 1985, and a major transition took place at that time. BAE Systems took it over in 1987. It is worth bearing it in mind that there have been closures of significant parts of that enterprise over the years. To mention just a few, Enfield closed in 1988; Patricroft closed in 1989, as did Waltham Abbey; and Westcott closed in 1994. That was well before the time of this Administration and well before my time.

Was the realm threatened as a consequence? No, it was not. Why was that action required? To answer that, I would have to examine some of the issues, but there was probably a need for rationalisation, a better way of delivering what needed to be delivered. The then Conservative Government understood that that had to be examined and tested, and the decisions were taken. The very fact of closure is no sign of disrespect to those who have shown commitment and delivered a high-quality service in years past. Sometimes, closure is needed to ensure the best delivery. Much of what we are doing now involves taking the same factors into account. We are, of course, doing much more besides.

The defence industrial strategy provided clarity on the MOD's thinking in a variety of sectors, including general munitions. In it, we recognised explicitly the military importance of general munitions. I do not believe that there is any difference between us on that. Paragraph B6.3 on page 95 states that

"quality general munitions, including Small Arms Ammunition, are essential to provide the volumes of fire and the 24 hour, all weather capability required to suppress, neutralise and demoralise enemy forces".
The hon. Gentleman knows better than I do what that means in practice.

The chapter outlined critical capabilities that we want to retain and develop in the industrial base, which included the manufacture of certain munitions—not all but particularly insensitive munitions and polymer bonded explosives to ensure that the safety hazards inherent in those weapons are as low as is reasonably practicable. We consulted industry throughout the process.

The hon. Gentleman will know that BAE Systems provides us with the majority—80 per cent. of repeat buys—of our general munitions capability under a long-term framework partnering agreement dating back to 1999. The FPA has provided us with security of supply and contributed to the delivery of an effective general munitions capability that has stood the test of numerous operations since its inception. However, given the particular importance of munitions to our overall military capability, this is an area where we cannot afford to stand still, and we are continually reviewing how best to ensure security of supply—that is uppermost in our mind—and the best value for money for the taxpayer. That is no different from the situation in all those years past when the general munitions environment was undergoing such radical change.

As part of that ongoing work and coincident with the DIS work, we reaffirmed last September our long-term requirement for general munitions and signed a partnering principles agreement with BAE Systems setting out how we might work together in the future. That was informed by our DIS capability assessments. We set out the assessments and then talked to industry to ascertain whether we could apply that partnering arrangement, which applies to general munitions, consistently across a range of platform and other equipment deliveries.

As a consequence of those decisions, BAE Systems made commercial decisions involving the closure of two of its munitions sites at Chorley and Bridgwater—Bridgwater, obviously, being the hon. Gentleman's constituency. I can well understand his concern about the Bridgwater site, but I should point out that this is a commercial decision for the company as it responds to the wider market place and the DIS, and considers what is best for defence as a whole.

I should make it absolutely clear that we have taken steps to ensure that our military capability will not be weakened by this process. We have worked hard with the company and received the assurances that we need about safeguarding the supply of material, which will no longer be directly provided by BAE Systems as a result of its decisions. So we have put all that under test, using the same criteria as were laid down by the hon. Gentleman. The company wrote to the Defence Committee on 13 February this year, elaborating in detail on the safeguards that we have jointly agreed. No doubt that will be given due weight by the Committee when it reports.

As part of the guarantee, BAE Systems is establishing a strategic stockpile of Bridgwater-produced material to support our forces for the foreseeable future. That is an important aspect; as well as taking the assurances and guarantees, we also have a stockpile so that we can sustain our needs into the foreseeable future. The company also discussed with us how it will undertake its assessments when sourcing material from overseas, and made it clear that secure sources of supply will be a key factor in any decisions. We strongly support the company's efforts to raise efficiency across its business in general and, in particular, to create a sustainable future for general munitions production in the UK, while ensuring value for money for the taxpayer.

The partnering principles also give the opportunity to improve the delivery of military capability to the armed forces. The BAE Systems site at Glascoed in south Wales will become a centre of excellence in the development of insensitive munitions materials such as PBX, which I mentioned earlier. There will be considerable investment at the Glascoed site to allow that to take place. It is not as if we are throwing everything out; indeed, we are satisfied that the company has taken rational decisions, and it is also investing in key capabilities.

The hon. Gentleman should be aware that the Department is also in partnering arrangements with other munitions suppliers such as Wallop Defence Systems, based in the UK, and Rheinmetall AG, based in Germany. To sum up on the issue of munitions: our work in this area will provide better capability at better value for money in this important sector.

I thank the Minister for his generosity and am intrigued by what he has said. He knows better than anybody in the Chamber that the stress of going into action and supplying the equipment—getting it to the right place at the right time—is phenomenal.

During the first Gulf war, the noble Lord King, the then Defence Secretary, was told by the Belgians that they would not supply machine gun ammunition. If that happens in such a situation, there is a problem. If we depend on the French or South Africans or Americans and they say, "No, we do not want to do this", ammunition will be the first thing to run out. It is the thing that is most prolifically used—bombs, missiles, the lot. The assurance given by the Minister and the noble Lord Drayson is fine as far as it goes, but there is no guarantee at the end of the day that the country involved would allow us to have the stuff if it disagreed on moral grounds with what the British Government of the day were doing.

I well recognise that point, and I make this one. We work within a set of relationships, whether NATO or EU relationships. There is a greater amount of interdependency and there are greater efforts, improving the success levels of interoperability. All those things must now take place, because no one nation can effectively deliver all the capabilities that they need. Even the United States, during the Afghan conflict, had to call on NATO's airborne warning and control systems. Indeed, it was German planes that flew over the US skies because the US's surveillance aircraft were—correctly—heavily engaged in tracking down the evil force that attacked it on 9/11. I well understand that.

The hard logic of what the hon. Gentleman is saying is that we should produce everything ourselves; we should be producing all stocks and all our equipment, and there should be no purchasing from abroad. It is not just a question of ammunition—and there is no question at all about how vital ammunition is. A spare that keeps a helicopter flying, or any nuts and bolts that could be critical to mission success, could fall into the same category, although they do not have the same immediacy for infantry in the front line. However, to someone flying an aircraft, such parts can still be as important, in terms of getting it wrong. That is perhaps a weakness in what the hon. Gentleman is saying, but I am not denying the importance of ensuring security of supply; that is vital.

I can tell the hon. Gentleman that we already have the stocks necessary to meet the defence planning assumptions. To sum up in one phrase, we could go to war now. We do not need to wait for those in the supply chain to say that they can supply. That has been proven consistently. I recognise some of the issues that have been raised in the past, and that is why we go through training exercises. I have been a Defence Minister for four and a half years now. I remember the Saif Sareea 2 training exercise, which took place at the same time as the conflict in Afghanistan. The debate was whether we should go ahead with that exercise. The decision was taken do so, although it put a considerable strain on the system, because we had valuable lessons to learn, and those lessons were absolutely critical. The exercise did expose issues within the defence logistics organisation. We have taken on board those critical lessons and we are now moving forward. General munitions fall within that area. I am sorry that the commercial decisions have impacted adversely on the hon. Gentleman's constituency and I am sorry for the people who work in that factory, but at the end of the day I do not think for a moment that the defence of the realm is threatened by what we are seeking to do.
Question put and agreed to.
Adjourned accordingly at three minutes to Five o'clock.
